awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Assessing climate-biosphere linkages using Late Holocene records of climate variability and vegetation dynamics from the Brazilian Amazon and Savanna
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project aims to investigate the role of changes in the South American Summer Monsoon (SASM) intensity on forest-savanna biome shifts that occurred during the Late Holocene.  Development of paleoclimate records from in and near the core of the monsoon region enables an assessment of the strength of the paleo-monsoon signal across the region.

The researchers look to generate independent, yet co-located, records of past climate (speleothems) and vegetation (soil profiles) dynamics from the Brazilian Amazon and Cerrado (savanna), for which existing records are absent. Paleoclimate and ecological interpretations will be validated using cave monitoring and proxy system modeling.

The researchers intend to evaluate the following questions: i) Do speleothem delta 18-Oxygen values reflect variations in SASM intensity, ii) Do variations in SASM intensity drive corresponding variation in local moisture conditions, iii) What was the nature and driver of Late Holocene variability in SASM intensity and local moisture conditions, and iv) how sensitive were biomes in vegetative transition zones to variability in SASM intensity and local moisture conditions. 

The project involves the monitoring of modern cave environments to evaluate speleothem delta 18-Oxygen values as a proxy of SASM intensity and speleothem trace element concentrations and Strontium isotope compositions as a proxy of local moisture conditions.  The research will extend existing speleothem delta 18-Oxygen records of the last millennium from the Amazon and Cerrado further back in time and develop corresponding records of speleothem trace element and 87- Strontium /86-Strontium and soil organic matter delta 13-Carbon to assess the co-variability between regional monsoon intensity, local moisture conditions, and biome shifts.

The project helps promote greater understanding of the SASM and strong collaboration with Brazilian scientists.  The SASM is the most important source of rainfall to the region with great socio-economic and environmental relevance, including defining current ecosystem distribution and stability, hydroelectric production, and agriculture.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project include advancements in the understanding of caves and how calcium carbonates deposited in caves (speleothems) record information about past climates and environments. Carbon dioxide is produced belowground by the decay of plant material and by the activity of plants roots. Carbon dioxide is produced by respiration, which consumes oxygen gas (O2). The air belowground (with elevated CO2 and depleted O2), such as the air in caves, exchanges with air in the atmosphere. When this exchange is slow, CO2 can build up to high levels belowground (and O2 can be lowered substantially below atmospheric levels). High CO2 levels inhibit the formation of speleothems.  In this project, we determined that three caves in Brazil ventilate (exchange air with the atmosphere) due to cave-atmosphere temperature contrasts. In austral winter, outside air is denser than cave air, causing ventilation. Ventilation of these caves also occurs on daily and weekly timescales. Seasonal ventilation of midlatitude caves has already been documented, this study contributed to the understanding of ventilation of low latitude (near the equator) caves.

The carbon that makes up the calcium carbonate in speleothems in these caves records information about past environments, the environment at the time that the calcium carbonate formed. When water drips into caves, some of the carbon in the water is emitted in the cave air as CO2. This process is especially prevalent when a cave is well ventilated and cave air CO2 concentrations are low and near atmospheric levels. By analyzing records of the carbon isotope composition of Brazilian speleothems, we determined that this the most important process causing variability in the speleothem carbon. Because this process varies with the rate of water dripping into caves, we established that carbon isotope ratios in Brazilian speleothems provide records of the monsoonal rainfall and its variability through time in this region.

Finally, we used XRCT scanning (similar to medical CAT scans) to image speleothems before cutting them for analytical work. We found that scanning can help locate the central axis along which a stalagmite (a speleothem that grows upward from the cave floor) grew. This is critical for the use of stalagmites to reconstruct past climates because some of the chemical and especially isotopic compositions vary from the central growth axis outward. Stalagmites are therefore ideally sampled at their growth axis. XRCT scanning can help determine the optimal plane for cutting samples.
